title: Fourier Analysis Meets Runtime Analysis: Precise Runtimes on Plateaus
abstract:
Abstract
We propose a new method based on discrete Fourier analysis to analyze the time evolutionary algorithms
spend on plateaus. This immediately gives a concise proof of the classic estimate of the expected runtime of the (1+1)11(1+1) evolutionary algorithm on the Needle
problem due to Garnier, Kallel, and Schoenauer (1999).
We also use this
method to analyze the runtime of the (1+1)11(1+1) evolutionary algorithm on a
benchmark consisting of n/‚Ñìùëõ‚Ñìn/\ell plateaus of effective size 2‚Ñì‚àí1superscript2‚Ñì12^{\ell}-1 which
have to be optimized sequentially in a LeadingOnes fashion.
Using our new method, we determine
the precise expected runtime both for static and fitness-dependent
mutation rates. We also determine the asymptotically optimal static and fitness-dependent mutation rates.
For ‚Ñì=o‚Äã(n)‚Ñìùëúùëõ\ell=o(n), the optimal static mutation rate is approximately 1.59/n1.59ùëõ1.59/n. The optimal fitness dependent mutation rate, when the first kùëòk fitness-relevant bits have been found, is asymptotically 1/(k+1)1ùëò11/(k+1). These results, so far only proven for the single-instance problem LeadingOnes, thus hold for a much broader class of problems. We expect similar extensions to be true for other important results on LeadingOnes. We are also optimistic that our Fourier analysis approach can be applied to other plateau problems as well.
